title: Yes, it’s true: Dunkin’ is selling iced coffee in 48-ounce buckets
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Dunkin' introduces 48-ounce iced coffee buckets for a limited time at select New England locations.
The coffee buckets, priced starting at $8.89, double the size of a medium 24-ounce Dunkin' iced coffee.
Availability is uncertain; some locations reportedly have sold out, while others have not yet stocked the buckets.

title: What Raiders GM John Spytek said about Maxx Crosby trade rumors
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Raiders GM John Spytek expects Maxx Crosby to remain with the team despite ongoing trade rumors after a 3-14 season.
Crosby signed a three-year, $106 million extension last March and recently had surgery to repair a torn meniscus.
Spytek acknowledges Crosby trade talks but emphasizes the need for elite players in team building, stressing he is "always listening."

title: Platner maintains big lead over Mills in Maine senate race, new poll finds
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Graham Platner leads Maine Gov. Janet Mills 64% to 26% in the Democratic Senate primary, per a UNH poll.
Platner has a 49% to 38% lead over Republican Sen. Susan Collins in a projected general election, according to UNH.
Platner, 41, a progressive newcomer, retains strong support despite past controversies with a chest tattoo and social media posts.

title: R.I. college student dies of carbon monoxide poisoning while charging cellphone in car
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Joseph Boutros, 21, died from carbon monoxide poisoning in Newport, R.I., after charging his cellphone in a snow-covered car.
Boutros was found unconscious with the car's exhaust pipe embedded in snow during a record-setting nor'easter.
Authorities emphasize clearing snow from car exhausts to prevent such tragedies; Salve Regina mourns Boutros's loss.

title: Mass. hiker suffering medical emergency rescued from White Mountains
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: A 75-year-old Acton, Massachusetts, hiker was rescued from Zealand Hut in White Mountains due to a medical emergency.
New Hampshire Fish and Game assisted the hiker down a trail and transported him by snowmobile to an ambulance.
The hiker was taken to Littleton Regional Hospital for treatment; authorities praised the group's preparedness.

title: Man arrested for allegedly throwing dog off balcony while drunk in Milford
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Alex De Oliveira, 25, was arrested for allegedly throwing a dog off a balcony in Milford while intoxicated.
The incident occurred at Oak Ridge Apartments; the severely injured dog was found in a snowbank and given medical aid.
De Oliveira faces charges including animal cruelty and was released on $5,000 bail; the dog is being treated at Tufts Animal Hospital.

title: 5 takeaways from Eliot Wolf’s press conference at the NFL Scouting Combine
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Eliot Wolf discussed the Patriots' offseason priorities at the NFL Scouting Combine, focusing on player management and development.
Wolf confirmed reports of interest in tackle Rasheed Walker are false, despite tackle depth being a concern for the Patriots.
The team is undecided on Stefon Diggs' future, as they continue to evaluate roster improvements through free agency and trades.

title: Mass. girl, 11, killed in Utah avalanche while vacationing with family
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: 11-year-old Madelyn Eitas from Rochester, Massachusetts, died in a Utah avalanche near Brighton Ski Resort last Thursday.
Eitas was found by her brother using an app during a search involving 20 people; she died despite medical efforts.
Rochester's schools and soccer community mourn Eitas, offering counseling services and dedicating the soccer season in her memory.

title: Dorchester women injured after snowmobile hits multiple trees in N.H.
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Two Dorchester women were injured in a snowmobile crash in Columbia, New Hampshire on Friday.
The 30-year-old first-time operator lost control, causing the snowmobile to hit multiple trees.
Both women were taken to Upper Connecticut Valley Hospital after being transported by Colebrook Fire Department.

title: Frederick Wiseman, the Bostonian who changed filmmaking forever
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Frederick Wiseman, a pioneer in documentary filmmaking, passed away at 96, renowned for his unique and contemplative style.
Wiseman's breakthrough film 'Titicut Follies' was banned in Massachusetts for over 20 years due to its depiction of a state-run hospital.
His acclaimed works like 'Welfare' and 'City Hall' offer immersive, narrative-free looks at everyday American life and institutions.
